title_sort: louisa van velsor whitman to walt whitman, 29 june [1870]
title: Louisa Van Velsor Whitman to Walt Whitman, 29 June [1870]
text: 29 June '69June 29Well waltwe have lived through the heat so far the heat has been bad enoughfenough but i could have born it but i have had a real bad time with the rheumatism last saturdaySaturday toward evening i went up on the hill i went by the way of cumberland stCumberland Street and set down several times before i reached the top whether it was that or what i dontdon't know but all that night i couldentcouldn't sleep my legs pained me so very bad and sunday but tuesdayTuesday they didentdidn't pain me so bad but left me pretty lame but i have kept around slowly made edd doodo all i could i suppose it was coming down the hill strained the nerves so i think i shantshan't go on fort greenFort Greene again i am well otherways but such pain as i had for two or three days) and to mend the matter i had one of mr heyde sheyde's complimentorycomplimentary letters over a sheet of foolscap i read part of it and kindled the fire with it) walt if Mrs OconorO'Connor and Jenney comes i will make them very welcome and treat them very kindly but i cantcan't doodo as if i wasentwasn't lame but i shall get along very well it dontdon't hurt me so bad quite to day to walk as it did yesterday) george hasenthasn't been home in a long while i haventhaven't heard a word from him he said if i got out of money i must write to him but i aintain't out yet i have felt sometimes quite uneasy about him as he is liable to be affected with the sun and he had to go to florenceFlorence to inspect the new yorkNew York pipe) matty is not or wasentwasn't the last i heard so well she and the children talked of going to minnesotaMinnesota the children has had the whooping coughfcough and they dontdon't seem to get over it Walt you must keep a good heart that teedioustedious thumb will come all right i hope Louisa Van Velsor Whitman to Walt Whitman, 29 June [1870]
